channel.title: The theory and practice of communism
channel.description:
The Theory and Practice of Communism is a series of lectures taken from the 1967 Wisconsin Alumni seminar held at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. The speaker, Michael B. Petrovich, is a specialist in Russian and Balkan history, a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin, and the author of numerous articles and books.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

image.title: The theory and practice of communism

item.title: Stalinism and After, reel 2
item.description: In the second part of this lecture, Professor Petrovich continues to address the contradiction of Joseph Stalin's leadership--his desire to maintain state power while pursuing the Marxist doctrine of a classless state--as well as political maneuvering by the leadership of the USSR after his death.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: The Yugoslav Way to Socialism, Part 2, reel 1
item.description: In June, 1940, Joseph Stalin ordered Yugoslavia's expulsion from the Information Bureau of the Communist and Workers' Parties as the first step towards the extermination of Josip Broz Tito and his supporters. Although Tito's end seemed imminent, today, nearly 20 years later, not only is Tito alive but he is flourishing. In this two-part lecture, Professor Petrovich described the unique nature of Yugoslavian socialism.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: Yugoslavia--Politics and government--1945-1980

item.title: Nature and Importance of Communism, reel 2
item.description: Communism, as an idea, has had enormous success in a relatively short time in grasping the minds of men. In this, the first episode of the series, Professor Petrovich begins to define the differences between socialism and communism as well as the attraction that this idea has for so many people.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Marxism as a Philosophy, reel 1
item.description: According to Professor Petrovich, Marxism is not just another socioeconomic theory but pretends to be a complete system of thought, a total outlook on all of existence. He describes the philosophy of diamat, or dialectic materialism, a primary Soviet doctrine.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Stalinism and After, reel 1
item.description: In this lecture, Professor Petrovich addresses the contradiction of Joseph Stalin's leadership--his desire to maintain state power while pursuing the Marxist doctrine of a classless state--as well as political maneuvering by the leadership of the USSR after his death.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Evolution of Non-Marxian Socialism, part 1, reel 1
item.description: According to Professor Petrovich, Marxian socialism--or communism--is only one form of socialism. In this two-part lecture, he shares historical examples, starting from ancient times, involving approaches to common ownership of the means of production and the equal distribution of goods.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: The Yugoslav Way to Socialism, Part 1, reel 1
item.description: In June, 1940, Joseph Stalin ordered Yugoslavia's expulsion from the Information Bureau of the Communist and Workers' Parties as the first step towards the extermination of Josip Broz Tito and his supporters. Although Tito's end seemed imminent, today, nearly 20 years later, not only is Tito alive but he is flourishing. In this two-part lecture, Professor Petrovich described the unique nature of Yugoslavian socialism.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: Yugoslavia--Politics and government--1945-1980

item.title: World Communism Today, reel 1
item.description: In his final lecture, Professor Petrovich states that it is no longer accurate to define "world communism" as a monolithic force. He surveys communist nations and national parties, describing their political philosophies and positions on international issues, and their sphere of influence throughout the world.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: World Communism Today, reel 2
item.description: In his final lecture, Professor Petrovich states that it is no longer accurate to define "world communism" as a monolithic force. He surveys communist nations and national parties, describing their political philosophies and positions on international issues, and their sphere of influence throughout the world.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Marxism as an Ethic and a Secular Religion, reel 1
item.description: Professor Petrovich examines the religious and ethical aspects of communism, including adherents' comment powerful conviction that is is necessary to change the world.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Marxism as a Philosophy, reel 2
item.description: According to Professor Petrovich, Marxism is not just another socioeconomic theory but pretends to be a complete system of thought, a total outlook on all of existence. He describes the philosophy of diamat, or dialectic materialism, a primary Soviet doctrine.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.description: According to Professor Petrovich, Marxian socialism--or communism--is only one form of socialism. In this two-part lecture, he shares historical examples, starting from ancient times, involving approaches to common ownership of the means of production and the equal distribution of goods.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: The Yugoslav Way to Socialism, Part 1, reel 2
item.description: In June, 1940, Joseph Stalin ordered Yugoslavia's expulsion from the Information Bureau of the Communist and Workers' Parties as the first step towards the extermination of Josip Broz Tito and his supporters. Although Tito's end seemed imminent, today, nearly 20 years later, not only is Tito alive but he is flourishing. In this two-part lecture, Professor Petrovich described the unique nature of Yugoslavian socialism.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: Yugoslavia--Politics and government--1945-1980

item.title: Marx and Engels, reel 1
item.description: Professor Petrovich turns his attention to Marxian socialism and its founders, Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels. Friedrich Engels was not just a shadow of the master, as some people believe, but very much an author in his own right as well as the founder of the Marxist doctrine.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: The Way of Mao Tse-Tung, reel 1
item.description: By 1949 the Chinese were at the end of their rope--by their own tradition and leadership--and had a need for the kind of approach developed by Mao Zedong and his people. In this lecture, Professor Petrovich discusses the historical basis for and aftermath of the Chinese Communist Revolution.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Marxism as a Theory of History, part 1, reel 1
item.description: In this lecture, the first of two parts, Professor Petrovich discusses Marx's theory of history, which attempts to view history through the lens of Marxist ideology.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World Politics
